message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings suggest tetralogy of Fallot, which includes a ventricular septal defect. None of the other options are associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including central cyanosis and an enlarged cardiac silhouette with a narrowed mediastinum, suggest congenital heart disease. Among the options, a ventricular septal defect is most commonly associated with this presentation. The holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border is consistent with such a defect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest a diagnosis of Tetralogy of Fallot, which includes a ventricular septal defect. Option A refers to corrected transposition of the great arteries, option B refers to truncus arteriosus, and option C refers to atrioventricular canal defect, which are not consistent with the presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a congenital heart defect. The enlarged cardiac silhouette and narrowed mediastinum suggest an increase in blood flow to the heart due to shunting. Among the options, the most likely is a ventricular septal defect, which is a hole in the wall separating the right and left ventricles, allowing oxygen-poor blood from the right ventricle to mix with oxygen-rich blood from the left ventricle. This mixing results in decreased oxygen saturation and cyanosis. The holosystolic murmur heard over the left lower sternal border is consistent with this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn has central cyanosis, which suggests some type of congenital heart defect. The X-ray shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette with a narrowed mediastinum, which suggests that the newborn has congestive heart failure. Among the options, only Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) is associated with a holosystolic murmur heard over the left lower sternal border. VSD is a congenital heart defect in which there is a hole in the wall separating the two lower chambers of the heart. This can cause blood to flow from the left ventricle to the right ventricle instead of flowing to the body. This can result in a decrease in oxygenation of blood and lead to central cyanosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn’s symptoms indicate a congenital heart defect. The narrowed mediastinum suggests the presence of ventricular septal defect, which is a common congenital heart defect characterized by a hole in the wall separating the two ventricles of the heart.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn’s symptoms and examination findings suggest a congenital heart defect. Among the options, only a ventricular septal defect (VSD) can cause cyanosis and a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border. The enlarged cardiac silhouette suggests that the baby’s heart is working harder than usual to compensate for the VSD. Alignment of infundibular septum, division of aorta and pulmonary artery, and fusion of endocardial cushion are associated with other types of congenital heart defects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including central cyanosis and an enlarged cardiac silhouette with a narrowed mediastinum, suggested a congenital heart defect. Among the options, only ventricular septal defect (VSD) can cause these symptoms. The holosystolic murmur and single second heart sound are also consistent with VSD. Alignment of infundibular septum, division of aorta and pulmonary artery, and fusion of endocardial cushion are all types of congenital heart defects, but they are not associated with the specific symptoms described in the case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the newborn has a congenital heart defect. The enlarged cardiac silhouette with a narrowed mediastinum indicates a potential left-to-right shunt. Among the options, ventricular septal defect (VSD) is the most associated with a left-to-right shunt and holosystolic murmur. Alignment of infundibular septum, division of aorta and pulmonary artery, and fusion of endocardial cushion are not commonly associated with these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms presented by the newborn suggest the presence of a congenital heart defect. The enlarged cardiac silhouette and narrowed mediastinum on the chest X-ray suggest Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) as the most likely diagnosis. A VSD is a hole in the wall that separates the two lower chambers of the heart, which can cause oxygen-poor blood to mix with oxygen-rich blood. Alignment of the infundibular septum is associated with Tetralogy of Fallot, division of the aorta and pulmonary artery is associated with Transposition of Great Arteries, and fusion of endocardial cushion is associated with Atrial Septal Defect.
